title.narrative: PK Punjab Barrages Improvement Phase II Project (PBIP-II)

description.narrative: The overarching project objectives are to assist the Borrower in (i) rehabilitating and modernizing Jinnah Barrage and carrying outaffiliated works to enable reliable and uninterrupted supply of water for over 2.1 million acres of farmland benefitting about600,000 farm families for irrigation and domestic water users; and (ii) build Punjab Irrigation and Power Department's capacity inimproved water resources and irrigation system management.

condition.narrative: Project Agreement: Schedule, Section 1, A 1 (a): Description: Punjab to maintain,

title.narrative: IPD’s increased functional capacity to manage water resources and irrigation system in the Province using modern tools and equipment

baseline.value: (current level of water management) Water accounting and allocation decisions being made through traditional and manual methods andpractices

target.value: Better water allocation and accounting over 50 percent of the area

actual.value: The PMIU is now doing improved water accounting based on modern systems over 100 percent of the irrigation system. The PMIU hasalso recently taken over the responsibility for determining intra-Punjab water allocations with the help of the recently completedDSS. This improved water allocation system is expected to cover 100 percent of the irrigation system by July 2017.

title.narrative: Component C: Baseline of monitoring is prepared and supervision of EMP and SDAP is carried out

baseline.value: 2009: No baseline data available and no environmental and social plan exists

actual.value: Baseline, mid-term and end-of-project surveys completed and findings documented in various M&E reports. Environmental and SocialDevelopment Plans developed and satisfactorily implemented. PHED completed 35 water supply schemes in Saline Zones of MohajirBranch Canal Command and handed over to the users. A seed distribution program successfully completed. Various other socialinfrastructure completed, notably the Kalabagh railway bridge was rehabilitated and opened to traffic, reducing daily traveldistance and time for resident of Kalabagh town.

title.narrative: Component D: Project implementation is coherent and contracts are awarded; No interruption to river and canal supplies.

target.value: All project activities satisfactorily completed. Normal supplies to canal river system.

actual.value: All contracts for works, goods and services substantially completed satisfactorily and in a timely manner. No interruptions towater supply to Thal Canal because of project activities. Training activities ongoing

baseline.value: All gates have manual control; some gates malfunction; and operation is inefficient due to aging factors and large size.

actual.value: All gates renovated and provided with remote control through SCADA system and direct motorization as well besides manual control

title.narrative: Barrage able to pass floods safely

baseline.value: Barrage and its associated structures vulnerable to damage during floods

target.value: Barrage is better equipped to handle floods safely

actual.value: After rehabilitation and modernization the barrage is better equipped to handle floods safely

target.value: Rehabilitation and modernization work fully completed and new systems operational

actual.value: All physical works completed and new systems operational.

title.narrative: Retrogression Downstream of the Barrage is stopped

baseline.value: There is heavy scouring/ retrogression immediately downstream threatening it’s safety. River bed erosion up to 25 feet deep wasobserved 1000 feet to 15000 feet downstream of the Barrage

actual.value: Bathymetric survey carried out after completion of the main works shows that retrogression has stopped

title.narrative: No reduction of water supplies to the Thal canal.

baseline.value: Unreliable and lower than the design flows in Thal canal due to poor condition of barrage gates. Supplies to the canals lower thandesign during January to April and Nov. to December

target.value: Reliable water supply as a result of improved operation of barrage and Thal canal head regulator after rehab

actual.value: Reliable water supply as a result of improved operation of barrage and Thal canal head regulator after rehab

title.narrative: Barrage able to supply reliable and uninterrupted water supply to over 2.1 million acres of farmland benefitting about 600,000 farm families for irrigation and domestic water users

baseline.value: Water supply to Thal Canal unreliable;DPR value 0.58

target.value: Less interruption in water supplies to the Thai canal area

actual.value: Water supply to the Thal canal that serves 2.1 million acres benefitting about 600,000 farm families has improved after barragerehab. DPR value during 2016, i.e. after completion of main works, is estimated at 0.72, which means that water supply to the ThalCanal is “reliable”

title.narrative: Component B: Management Information: - water accounting system; Modern equipment in monitoring and management of hydraulic infrastructure

baseline.value: -- Modern systems and equipment not in place for: real time flow measurement (RTFM), Water Resources Management Information System,Water Accounting, and Decision Support Systems (DSS) for intra-provincial water allocations; Supervisory Controls for DataAcquisition (SCADA) for barrage operation; bathymetric survey equipment, CCTV, etc,--staff not conversant with modern technologyand tools for barrage safety, surveillance--functional piezometers for subsurface flows, automatic sensors for water level andflow metering and links with the Jinnah Hydro-Power Project’s operations and gate opening, not in place--Water allocationdecisions being made based on traditional and manual methods

actual.value: --Equipment procured and installed --SCADA system operational--Barrage staff trained in various fields including SCADA --PMIU staff training in DSS ongoing--Water Resources Management Information System linked with real time flow Monitoring--20staff completed post-graduate degrees and received further overseas training--Water Accounting based on modern system on 100percent of the irrigation system. It is expected that by July, 2017 water allocation decisions will also be based on DSS.
